name: EPIC Institute of Technology Round Summer 2025 (Codeforces Round 1036, Div. 1 + Div. 2)

problems.title: Deranged Deletions
problems.statementHtml:
Call an array bb of length mm a derangement if the following property holds:

For example,

You are given an array aa of length nn. In one operation, you can delete an element from aa. The order of the remaining elements is preserved after each deletion.

Output whether it is possible to perform some (possibly none) operations such that the remaining elements form a derangement. If it is possible, output any possible remaining array. The remaining array must be non-empty.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤1001≤n≤100) — the length of array aa.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — denoting the array aa.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, on a new line, if it is possible to perform operations such that the remaining array is a derangement, output YES. Otherwise, output NO.

You can output in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.

If your response was positive, output two more lines in the following format:

  • The first line should contain an integer kk (1≤k≤n1≤k≤n), the number of elements that remain in the array.
  • The second line should contain d1,d2…,dkd1,d2…,dk, the elements that remain in the array. It must be possible to acquire array dd after performing some operations on aa. Array dd must be a derangement.
problems.noteHtml: In the second test case, we can delete one 55 from the array so that it becomes [4,5,2,4][4,5,2,4]. It can be shown this array is a derangement. This is not the only solution – it can be shown that the original array [4,5,5,2,4][4,5,5,2,4] is another valid solution.

problems.title: Minimise Sum
problems.statementHtml:
This problem differs from problem G. In this problem, you must output the minimum sum of prefix minimums after at most one operation.

You are given an array aa of length nn, with elements satisfying 0≤ai≤n0≤ai≤n. You can perform the following operation at most once:

Output the minimum possible value of min(a1)+min(a1,a2)+…+min(a1,a2,…,an)min(a1)+min(a1,a2)+…+min(a1,a2,…,an) that you can get.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — the length of aa.

The following line contains nn space-separated integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n0≤ai≤n) — denoting the array aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output an integer on a new line, the minimum possible value of min(a1)+min(a1,a2)+…+min(a1,a2,…,an)min(a1)+min(a1,a2)+…+min(a1,a2,…,an).
problems.noteHtml:
In the second test case, it is optimal to perform the operation with i=2i=2 and j=3j=3.

In the third test case, it is optimal to not perform any operations. The answer is 33.

problems.title: Subset Multiplication
problems.statementHtml:
Alice has an array aa, consisting of nn positive integers. The array satisfies the beautiful property that aiai divides ai+1ai+1 for each 1≤i≤n−11≤i≤n−1.

Bob sees Alice's beautiful array and is jealous. To sabotage her, Bob first creates an array bb of size nn such that bi=aibi=ai for each 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n. Then, he chooses a positive integer xx and multiplies some (possibly none, possibly all) elements in bb by xx.

Formally, he chooses a (possibly-empty) subset S⊆{1,2,…,n}S⊆{1,2,…,n}, and for each i∈Si∈S, he sets bi:=bi⋅xbi:=bi⋅x.

You are given an array bb, but you don't know array aa and the chosen number xx. Please output any integer xx that Bob could choose, so that multiplying some subset of elements of the correct array aa by xx would result in array bb. It is guaranteed that the answer exists. If there are multiple possible integers, you can output any of them.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤2⋅1051≤t≤2⋅105). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤6⋅1052≤n≤6⋅105) — the length of the array bb.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers b1,b2,…,bnb1,b2,…,bn (1≤bi≤1091≤bi≤109) — denoting the array bb.

It is guaranteed the array bb can be obtained from some beautiful array aa and some positive integer xx as described in the statements.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 6⋅1056⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output any possible value of xx (1≤x≤1091≤x≤109) on a new line. It is guaranteed at least one value of xx exists.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, it is possible Bob selected x=343x=343 and S={}S={} (meaning he did not change the array aa at all).

In the third test case, it is possible Bob selected x=4x=4 and S={1,2}S={1,2}, meaning he multiplied both b1b1 and b2b2 by 44. The original array was {1,2,4,8}{1,2,4,8}, which satisfies the required property.

problems.title: Make a Palindrome
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array aa of size nn, and an integer kk. You may perform the following operation any number of times:

Determine if it is possible to get an array that is a palindrome∗∗ after any number of operations. Note that an empty array is considered a palindrome.

∗∗An array b=[b1,b2,…,bm]b=[b1,b2,…,bm] is a palindrome if for each 1≤i≤m1≤i≤m, bi=bm+1−ibi=bm+1−i.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line contains two integers nn and kk (1≤k≤n≤2⋅1051≤k≤n≤2⋅105).

The second line contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — denoting the array aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output YES if it is possible to create a palindrome, and NO otherwise. You can output in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, aa is already a palindrome.

In the second test case, we can perform two operations as follows: [1,1,2,1]→[1,2,1]→[1,1][1,1,2,1]→[1,2,1]→[1,1]

In the third test case, we can perform one operation as follows: [2,3,4,5,3,2]→[2,3,4,3,2][2,3,4,5,3,2]→[2,3,4,3,2].

In the fourth and fifth test cases, it can be shown it is impossible to create a palindrome no matter what operations are used.

samples.output:
YES
YES
YES
NO
NO
YES
NO
YES

problems.title: Make it Zero
problems.statementHtml:
You are given an array aa, consisting of nn positive integers. You are allowed to do the following operation:

Your task is to change all the elements to 00. Find the minimum number of operations required.

Then, output a way to perform the operations. If it is impossible to change all the elements of aa to 00 no matter how many operations are used, print −1−1 instead. It can be shown that under the constraints of this problem, the smallest number of operations required is at most 1717.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤5⋅1042≤n≤5⋅104) — the length of the array aa.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤10121≤ai≤1012) — denoting the array aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 5⋅1045⋅104.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, output −1−1 if there is no solution.

Otherwise, first output an integer ss (1≤s≤171≤s≤17) – the minimum number of operations to change all the elements of aa to 00.

Then, in the next ss lines, output nn integers in each line b1,b2,…,bn(0≤bi≤ai)b1,b2,…,bn(0≤bi≤ai) — denoting the array bb for each operation.

After performing the operations, all the elements of aa should be changed to 00.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, we can simply choose b=ab=a in our operation. This is valid because b1+b2=b3b1+b2=b3.

In the second test case, it can be proven that it is impossible to change all the elements of aa to 00.

problems.title: Appending Permutations (Easy Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the easy version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, n≤100n≤100. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

You are given an initially empty array aa. You may perform the following operation any number of times:

[r,r+1,…,s,1,2,…,r−1][r,r+1,…,s,1,2,…,r−1]

to the end of aa.

Your task is to count the number of distinct arrays of length exactly nn that can be constructed using the allowed operation and satisfy all of the given restrictions. Two arrays are considered different if they differ at any position from 11 to nn.

Print the answer modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1001≤t≤100). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n≤100,0≤m≤min(5000,n2)1≤n≤100,0≤m≤min(5000,n2)) — denoting the length of the array aa and the number of restrictions.

The following mm lines each contain two integers ii and xx (1≤i,x≤n1≤i,x≤n), indicating that ai≠xai≠x is a requirement of the final array. It is guaranteed that no limitation is given more than once.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 100100, and the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 50005000.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of arrays modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there are 77 total attainable arrays: [1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2],[1,1,2],[1,2,1],[2,1,1],[1,1,1][1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2],[1,1,2],[1,2,1],[2,1,1],[1,1,1].

In the second test case, none of the above 77 are valid because no element is allowed to be 11, and all of the arrays have at least one 11.

In the third case, only [2,3,1][2,3,1] is counted.

problems.title: Appending Permutations (Hard Version)
problems.statementHtml:
This is the hard version of the problem. The difference between the versions is that in this version, n≤5000n≤5000. You can hack only if you solved all versions of this problem.

You are given an initially empty array aa. You may perform the following operation any number of times:

[r,r+1,…,s,1,2,…,r−1][r,r+1,…,s,1,2,…,r−1]

to the end of aa.

Your task is to count the number of distinct arrays of length exactly nn that can be constructed using the allowed operation and satisfy all of the given restrictions. Two arrays are considered different if they differ at any position from 11 to nn.

Print the answer modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤50001≤t≤5000). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains two integers nn and mm (1≤n≤5000,0≤m≤min(5000,n2)1≤n≤5000,0≤m≤min(5000,n2)) — the length of the array aa and the number of restrictions.

The following mm lines each contain two integers ii and xx (1≤i,x≤n1≤i,x≤n), indicating that ai≠xai≠x is a requirement of the final array. It is guaranteed that no limitation is given more than once.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 50005000, and the sum of mm over all test cases does not exceed 50005000.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the number of arrays modulo 998244353998244353.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, there are 77 total attainable arrays: [1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2],[1,1,2],[1,2,1],[2,1,1],[1,1,1][1,2,3],[2,3,1],[3,1,2],[1,1,2],[1,2,1],[2,1,1],[1,1,1].

In the second test case, none of the above 77 are valid because no element is allowed to be 11, and all of the arrays have at least one 11.

In the third case, only [2,3,1][2,3,1] is counted.

problems.title: Maximise Sum
problems.statementHtml:
This problem differs from problem B. In this problem, you must output the maximum sum of prefix minimums over all operations that cost at least x for each integer x from 0 to n−1.

You are given an array a of length n, with elements satisfying 0≤ai≤n. You can perform the following operation at most once:

Let the cost of one operation be the value of j−i. The cost of not performing an operation is 0.

For each integer x from 0 to n−1 inclusive, output the maximum possible value of min(a1)+min(a1,a2)+…+min(a1,a2,…,an) over all possible operations that have a cost of at least x.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases t (1≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer n (2≤n≤106) — the length of a.

The following line contains n space-separated integers a1,a2,…,an (0≤ai≤n) — denoting the array a.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n over all test cases does not exceed 106.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output n integers on a new line: the i-th integer denoting the maximum answer over all operations that have a cost of at least i−1.
problems.noteHtml:
Let's analyze the fifth test case:

  • x=0,1,2: the optimal operation is i=2 and j=4, which has a cost of 2. The array a becomes [4,4,3,0,1], which has a score of 11.
  • x=3: the optimal operation is i=2 and j=5, which has a cost of 3. The array a becomes [4,2,3,3,0], which has a score of 10.
  • x=4: the optimal (and only) operation is i=1 and j=5, which has a cost of 4. The array a becomes [5,1,3,3,0], which has a score of 8.

problems.title: Longest Good Subsequence
problems.statementHtml:
Call an array bb of size mm good if the following conditions hold:

For example, the array [1,1,3,3,5][1,1,3,3,5] is good (where the permutation p=[2,1,5,3,4]p=[2,1,5,3,4] satisfies the second requirement), but the array [1,1,2][1,1,2] isn't.

Note the empty array is considered to be good.

You are given an array aa of size nn. Find the length of the longest good subsequence†† of aa.

∗∗A permutation of length mm is an array consisting of mm distinct integers from 11 to mm in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (m=3m=3 but there is 44 in the array).

††A sequence cc is a subsequence of a sequence dd if cc can be obtained from dd by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) element from arbitrary positions.
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (1≤n≤150001≤n≤15000) – the length of aa.

The second line of each test case contains nn integers a1,a2,…,ana1,a2,…,an (1≤ai≤n1≤ai≤n) — denoting the array aa.

It is guaranteed that the sum of n2n2 does not exceed 150002150002 over all test cases.
problems.outputSpecHtml: For each test case, output the length of the longest good subsequence of aa on a new line.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, the entire sequence is good.

In the second test case, the longest good subsequence is [1,2][1,2].

problems.title: Lexicographic Partition
problems.statementHtml:
Given an array aa, define f(a)f(a) as follows:

You are given nn integers x1,x2,…,xnx1,x2,…,xn. Please determine if there exists a permutation‡‡ aa such that f([a1,a2,…,ai])=xif([a1,a2,…,ai])=xi for each 1≤i≤n1≤i≤n. If there is a permutation, print one. If there are multiple possible answers, you may output any one.

∗∗An array cc is a subarray of an array dd if cc can be obtained from dd by the deletion of several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the beginning and several (possibly, zero or all) elements from the end.

††An array cc is lexicographically smaller than an array dd if and only if one of the following holds:

‡‡A permutation of length nn is an array consisting of nn distinct integers from 11 to nn in arbitrary order. For example, [2,3,1,5,4][2,3,1,5,4] is a permutation, but [1,2,2][1,2,2] is not a permutation (22 appears twice in the array), and [1,3,4][1,3,4] is also not a permutation (n=3n=3 but there is 44 in the array).
problems.inputSpecHtml:
Each test contains multiple test cases. The first line contains the number of test cases tt (1≤t≤1041≤t≤104). The description of the test cases follows.

The first line of each test case contains an integer nn (2≤n≤2⋅1052≤n≤2⋅105) — denoting the length of the array xx.

The following line contains nn integers x1,x2,…,xnx1,x2,…,xn (1≤xi≤i1≤xi≤i) — denoting the array xx.

It is guaranteed that the sum of nn over all test cases does not exceed 2⋅1052⋅105.
problems.outputSpecHtml:
For each test case, print YES if a permutation exists, and NO otherwise. Each letter may be outputted in uppercase or lowercase. You can output in any case (upper or lower). For example, the strings "yEs", "yes", "Yes", and "YES" will be recognized as positive responses.

If the answer is positive, output the permutation of nn numbers on the next line.
problems.noteHtml:
In the first test case, [1,2,3][1,2,3] is a valid permutation that satisfies the input array:

  • for [1][1], there is only one way to partition: partition a[1]a[1] by itself, so f([1])=1f([1])=1.
  • for [1,2][1,2], there are two ways to partition: [1,2][1,2] by itself or [1]+[2][1]+[2]. Constructing bb from the first partition yields b=[1]b=[1] and constructing bb from the second partition yields b=[1,2]b=[1,2]. The second one is lexicographically larger, so f([1,2])=2f([1,2])=2.
  • For [1,2,3][1,2,3], it can be shown the best partition is [1,2]+[3][1,2]+[3], yielding b=[1,3]b=[1,3].

In the second test case, it can be shown there are no permutations of size 22 with x1=x2=1x1=x2=1.

In the fourth test case, one permutation that satisfies the conditions is [3,1,2][3,1,2].

samples.output:
YES
1 2 3
NO
NO
YES
3 1 2
NO
YES
3 1 2 4
YES
1 4 3 5 2
YES
5 2 1 8 6 9 3 4 7

tutorial.contentHtml:
Thanks for participation! We hope you loved the contest.

2124A - Deranged Deletions

Problem Credits: Lilypad

Hint

When is there definitely not a solution?
